description: Borrowed from French ostensible, formed with the suffix -ible, from Latin ostensus, the past participle of ostendō (“show”), itself from obs- (“in front of”) (akin to ob- (“in the way”) and to Ancient Greek ἐπί (epí, “on, at, besides, after”) and Old English eofot (“crime”)) + tendō (“stretch”) (akin to Ancient Greek τείνω (teínō)). Cf. also Medieval Latin ostensibilis.

adjectives.description: ostensible (comparative more ostensible, superlative most ostensible)

entries.meaning: Apparent, evident; meant for open display.
examples: Motives, of course, may be mixed; but this only means that a man aims at a variety of goals by means of the same course of action. Similarly a man may have a strong motive or a weak one, an ulterior motive or an ostensible one.

entries.meaning: Appearing as such; being such in appearance; professed, supposed (rather than demonstrably true or real).
examples: The ostensible reason for his visit to New York was to see his mother, but the real reason was to get to the Yankees game the next day.
